html: The U.S. airline industry has committed to the following goals: -Improve fuel efficiency by 1.5% a year, starting in 2010. -Achieve carbon neutral growth starting next year. -Reduce net carbon dioxide emissions by 50% over 2005 levels by 2050. #ActOnClimate
text:
The U.S. airline industry has committed to the following goals: 

-Improve fuel efficiency by 1.5% a year, starting in 2010.
-Achieve carbon neutral growth starting next year.
-Reduce net carbon dioxide emissions by 50% over 2005 levels by 2050.

#ActOnClimate

html: Last week, we highlighted the recent Government shutdown’s impact on aviation. The price was high. -One U.S. airline reported losing $25 million in business. -14,000 air traffic controllers worked without pay. -The @NTSB stopped work on more than 1,800 safety investigations.
text:
Last week, we highlighted the recent Government shutdown’s impact on aviation.

The price was high.

-One U.S. airline reported losing $25 million in business.
-14,000 air traffic controllers worked without pay.
-The @NTSB stopped work on more than 1,800 safety investigations.

html: According to @NATCA, controller staffing at #FAA air traffic control facilities is already at a 30-year low. During the #shutdown, the FAA’s controller training academy was closed and new controllers were unable to complete their training. #AviationAtRiskpic.twitter.com/4TGT0cMjxO
text: According to @NATCA, controller staffing at #FAA air traffic control facilities is already at a 30-year low. During the #shutdown, the FAA’s controller training academy was closed and new controllers were unable to complete their training. #AviationAtRiskpic.twitter.com/4TGT0cMjxO

html: During the 35-day Government shutdown, between 30 and 40 percent of #FAA employees were furloughed, challenging the agency’s ability to fulfill its critical mandate to ensure the safe and efficient operation of our National Airspace System.
text: During the 35-day Government shutdown, between 30 and 40 percent of #FAA employees were furloughed, challenging the agency’s ability to fulfill its critical mandate to ensure the safe and efficient operation of our National Airspace System.

html: Fact: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) does not include any language that Mexico will pay for the border wall.
